0: Google is reportedly planning to get back into China, a lucrative market where it has a long history of tangling with authorities. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Intercept reported Wednesday that Google plans to launch a search app in China that would block sensitive websites and search terms to comply with Chinese government censorship. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR China has hundreds of millions of internet users and a thriving online shopping market, making it impossible for US tech companies to ignore. But jumping back into China presents ethical issues for Google (GOOGL), which has long advocated a free and open internet. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Andy Tian, a tech executive who formerly led mobile strategy and partnerships for Google in China, said the Chinese tech companies that currently dominate search can't compete with Google's product. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "There's a huge void, Google can fill that void," said Tian, who is now CEO of Asia Innovations. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Asked about The Intercept report, Google said in a statement that "we don't comment on speculation about future plans." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Related: Google's latest move to crack China: A WeChat game NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Like many other US internet platforms, Google's most popular products — search, YouTube, Gmail — have been banned in China for years, blacked out by a vast government censorship apparatus known as the Great Firewall. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR But that wasn't always the case. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Google China 1.0 NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Google launched a Chinese language version of its search engine — google.cn — in 2006. It complied with Beijing's censorship laws. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "While removing search results is inconsistent with Google's mission, providing no information (or a heavily degraded user experience that amounts to no information) is more inconsistent with our mission," Google said at the time. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Related: Google to censor itself in China NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR While the search engine was censored, it also flagged to users when information was removed from results. That gave Chinese internet users an idea of what they were not allowed to see. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We reminded users in China every single day that they are looking at filtered results," said Tian, who worked at Google when the search engine launched. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Still, critics complained that Google was breaching its own company motto: "Don't Be Evil." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The company's devotion to web freedom, critics charged, was being subverted by a willingness to comply with Chinese censorship in return for access to a huge potential customer base. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Attack and retreat NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Google was battling Baidu (BIDU) for market share. Three years after launch, Google had wrestled about a third of the search market away from its Chinese rival. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The dynamic changed in January 2010, when Google charged that Chinese hackers had targeted Google and more than 20 other Western companies and compromised the email accounts of Chinese dissidents living abroad. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Beijing denied that it had been involved in the attacks, but the incident sparked a political fight with Washington. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Related: Google quits censoring search in China NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR About three months later, Google made good on a threat to stop offering search in China. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In March 2010, it announced it had stopped running the censored Google.cn service and began routing its Chinese users to an uncensored version of Google based in Hong Kong. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Academics, university students and other researchers relied heavily on Google's search services to access information not available through Chinese search engines like Baidu. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Businesses that depended on Google applications such as Google Docs and Gmail also suffered. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Google wants back behind the Firewall NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Google's parent company Alphabet changed its motto in 2015, replacing "Don't Be Evil" with "Do the Right Thing." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR From a business perspective, getting back into China is the right thing for Google. It currently offers just a few services in the country — Google Translate, a file organizing program and a new AI game. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Advertising is Google's main source of revenue, and 1.4 billion potential users are hard to ignore. Facebook (FB), which competes with Google for advertising revenue, is also locked out of China. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Shares in Baidu (BIDU) dropped 8% on Wednesday after The Intercept report was published. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Related: Google bets $550M on Chinese e-commerce firm JD.com NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Critics and human rights groups are already accusing Google of bending to China's will. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The reality is that they will be serving the Chinese government," said Lokman Tsui, former head of free expression for Google in Asia. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The government now tracks people, apps on phones reveal who you are, where you are. They are intrusive," he added. "They collect much more data and Google can be requested to handover these data
